page.title: 19Chew Stoke Church
page.content: The Church at Chew Stoke, with its fine tower, was built in the 15th century by the{St. Loe}family whose coat of arms can be seen on the Rectory wall. After a fire, the Victorians restored the interior and put in one hundred and fifty-six stone and wood angels. The Church bells were made at the famous{bell foundary}here by the{Bilbie family}who were also clockmakers. Their bells hang in many local churches today. Still surviving in 1985 are two 700 year old yew trees in the churchyard and on either side of the gardener's shed are two richly carved Saxon stones. The Methodist Chapel in Chew Stoke is also still flourishing. It was built on land given by a farmer after{Wesley}had preached at his farmhouse nearby.
